## Load Data


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
tuesdata <- tidytuesdayR::tt_load(2026, week = 2)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr}

```
---- Compiling #TidyTuesday Information for 2026-01-13 ----
--- There is 1 file available ---


── Downloading files ───────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

  1 of 1: "africa.csv"
```


:::

```{.r .cell-code}
africa <- tuesdata$africa
```
:::


## Data Exploration


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
which(is.na(africa))
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
integer(0)
```


:::
:::



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
africa %>% 
  group_by_all() %>% 
  filter(n() > 1) %>% 
  ungroup()
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
# A tibble: 68 × 4
   language family      native_speakers country 
   <chr>    <chr>                 <dbl> <chr>   
 1 Afar     Afroasiatic         2500000 Ethiopia
 2 Afar     Afroasiatic         2500000 Djibouti
 3 Afar     Afroasiatic         2500000 Eritrea 
 4 Afar     Afroasiatic         2500000 Djibouti
 5 Afar     Afroasiatic         2500000 Eritrea 
 6 Afar     Afroasiatic         2500000 Ethiopia
 7 Bariba   Niger–Congo         1100000 Benin   
 8 Bariba   Niger–Congo         1100000 Benin   
 9 Bangi    Niger–Congo          120000 Congo   
10 Bangi    Niger–Congo          120000 Congo   
# ℹ 58 more rows
```


:::
:::



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
africa_clean <- unique(africa)
```
:::



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
africa_clean %>% 
  group_by_all() %>% 
  filter(n() > 1) %>% 
  ungroup()
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
# A tibble: 0 × 4
# ℹ 4 variables: language <chr>, family <chr>, native_speakers <dbl>,
#   country <chr>
```


:::
:::



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
africa_lang <- africa_clean %>% 
  group_by(country) %>% 
  tally(name = "num_langs_spoken")
```
:::



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
africa_lang$country <- tolower(africa_lang$country)
```
:::



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
africa_lang[rep(12,2),]
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
# A tibble: 2 × 2
  country num_langs_spoken
  <chr>              <int>
1 congo                 80
2 congo                 80
```


:::
:::



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
africa_lang1 <- rbind(africa_lang[-12,],africa_lang[rep(12,2),])
```
:::



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
africa_lang1[51, 1] = "democratic republic of the congo"
africa_lang1[52, 1] = "republic of the congo"
```
:::



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
africa_countries <- ne_countries(
  continent = "Africa",
  scale = "medium",
  returnclass = "sf"
)
```
:::



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
africa_countries$geounit <- tolower(africa_countries$geounit)
```
:::



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
africa_countries1 <- africa_countries %>% 
  select(geounit, geometry)
```
:::



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
africa_countries2 <- africa_countries1 %>% 
  left_join(africa_lang1, by = c("geounit" = "country"))
```
:::



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
ggplot(africa_countries2) +
  geom_sf(aes(fill = num_langs_spoken), color = "white", linewidth = 0.2) +
  scale_fill_viridis_c(option = "plasma") +
  labs(
    title = "Number of Languages Spoken in African Countries",
    caption = "Source: Natural Earth and Data Science Learning Community",
    fill = ""
  ) +
  theme_void()
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](tidytuesday26-1-12_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-16-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::


This map displays the number of languages spoken in various African countries. It should be noted that the original data did not include separate values for the Democratic Republic of the Congo and the Republic of the Congo so the value associated with "Congo" was duplicated in order to represent both countries on this map. It should also be noted that some countries included in the language data did not appear in the map data and vice versa most likely due to the language data being outdated and not reflecting current political realities.

In terms of general trends, it seems that countries closer to the center of Africa tend have more languages spoken within them. The countries on the North coast of Africa seem to have less languages spoken in them than other parts of Africa. The most languages are spoken in Cameroon with 96.
